FACT: Wishful thinking. These "mandatory" sequesters never get done because D.C. doesn't follow any of our own budget rules.

5. CLAIM: $56 billion in economic growth

I'm glad CBO is using dynamic scoring to take into account economic effects, which they should have done on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. Tax cuts create far more growth in the economy than federal spending.

This is a rosy estimate at best.

4. CLAIM: $53 billion from states returning unused federal enhanced unemployment benefits. 

FACT: Repurposing unused COVID relief funds we borrowed in the first place is not a real pay-for.

3. CLAIM: $49 billion in savings from delaying the Medicare Part D rebate rule.

FACT: Raising drug prices on seniors is not a pay-for, it's wrong.

2. CLAIM: Funding from recouping fraudulent enhanced federal unemployment payments.

FACT: Just like the "tax-gap," estimates for how much fraudulent UI was paid and how much can be recouped is conjecture.

Repurposing money the federal government previously wasted doesn't count.

1. CLAIM: $205 billion from repurposing unused COVID relief funds. 

FACT: We should be repurposing COVID relief funds, but reshuffling money we borrowed in the first place doesn't count as a pay-for.

Infrastructure investment is great when it's paid for. 

This bipartisan infrastructure package's pay-fors are either completely phony or don't quite cut the mustard.

Last week, @HouseJudiciary passed the #EQUALAct out of Committee. This long-overdue legislation now heads to the House floor where it is one step closer to ending the sentencing disparity between crack and powder cocaine once and for all.

10/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E7fFieXWQAQRpWn.jpg

The #EQUALAct would finally eliminate the crack cocaine and powder cocaine sentencing disparity. It would also allow individuals convicted or sentenced for a federal offense involving crack cocaine to petition for sentence reductions.

9/
https://www.vox.com/2021/3/19/22336224/equal-act-cocaine-sentencing-disparity-war-on-drugs

In 2019, 81% of individuals convicted of crack cocaine offenses were Black, while historically 66% of crack cocaine users have been white or Hispanic. An 18-to-1 disparity in sentencing is still too large.

8/
https://thehill.com/opinion/criminal-justice/540816-why-do-we-still-punish-crack-and-powder-cocaine-offenses-differently

Congress passed the Fair Sentencing Act of 2010, which reduced the drug quantity ratio from 100-to-1 to 18-to-1 for certain categories of drug offenses, and the First Step Act of 2018, which made the changes retroactive, meaning they could be applied to previous convictions.
 
7/

In 1997, 2002, and 2007, the Sentencing Commission issued updated reports that continued to urge Congress to reduce the ratio, citing that the current penalties were too broad and disproportionately impacted minorities.
https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2010/08/03/data-show-racial-disparity-in-crack-sentencing
 
6/

In 1995 the U.S. Sentencing Commission issued a report in which it unanimously recommended changes to the cocaine sentencing scheme, including revisiting the 100-to-1 ratio. The Commission cited ‚Äúinescapable‚Äù racial disparities in powder versus crack cocaine sentencing.

5/
